sentences.english: At the time of which I shall tell, the White Men were going down the river for the Hudson's Bay Company.
sentences.footnote: LB on {wêmistikôsiwak}:  Really “Frenchman”, but the term is often used for “white man” in general; this is here the case, if my understanding of {wîcihôwin} as “Hudson's Bay Company” is correct.  I have tried to analyze the incidents in this story in _Atti del XXII Congresso degli Americanisti_ (Rome, 1928) II, 23 ff.

sentences.original: êkwah kayâs êh-mâhamoht oskinîkiw pêyak wîcihiwêw.
sentences.text: êkwa kayâs ê-mâhamoht oskinîkiw pêyak wîcihiwêw
sentences.english: And when thus, long ago, they went down stream, a certain young man joined the Indians who were going along.

sentences.original: êwako ê-pê-kîwêyit owîcêwâkanah, kisâtam mâmihk, êh-wîwit êkotê, êh-otinât iskwêwa.
sentences.text: êwako ê-pê-kîwêyit owîcêwâkana kisâtam mâmihk ê-wîwit êkotê ê-otinât iskwêwa
sentences.english: Then, when his companions went home again, he stayed in the east, for he had taken a woman to wife there.

sentences.original: mwêhci êh-nisto-pipohk, êkoyikohk kâ-sipwêhtêt, êh-masinahikêt mac-ôhôw.
sentences.text: mwêhci ê-nisto-pipohk êkoyikohk kâ-sipwêhtêt ê-masinahikêt mac-ôhôw
sentences.english: Three years later Bad-Owl hired himself out to the Whites and went away from there.

sentences.original: nêtê itah êh-aywêpicik mâna, êkotê êy-askamâkocik omaskêkôwa pêyak.
sentences.text: nêtê ita ê-âywêpicik mâna êkotê ê-askamâkocik omaskêkôwa pêyak
sentences.english: Down yonder, at a place where they always stopped to rest, a certain Swampy Cree was awaiting their arrival.

sentences.original: mitâtasiyiwa owîkimâkana awa kisêyiniw, omaskêkôw, êh-manitôwit.
sentences.text: mitâtasiyiwa owîkimâkana awa kisêyiniw omaskêkôw ê-manitôwit
sentences.english: That old man, that Mushkago, had ten wives, for he was of manitou nature.

sentences.original: kostik sakâw-iyinîsa, osâm êh-manitôwit, mêyosiyici iskwêwa, sôskwâc êh-otinât.
sentences.text: kostik sakâw-iyinîsa osâm ê-manitôwit mêyosiyici iskwêwa sôskwâc ê-otinât
sentences.english: The Bush People feared him because he was of manitou nature: whenever there was a pretty woman, at once he would take her for himself.
If people resisted him, at once he would kill them.
In time thus, he came to be feared.

sentences.original: êkwah awa oskinîkiw, kêhcinâ wâpamâci ôhi niwîkimâkanah nka-maskamik awa kâ-manitôwit. osâm miyosiw niwîkimâkan, êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.english: Then that young man thought, “Surely, if he sees my wife, that manitou person will take her away from me. For my wife is beautiful.”
By this time they had a child, a boy; he was still in the swaddling bag.

sentences.original: êkwah aw ôskinîkiw, êkoyikohk mâna kâ-takosihkik ayîsiyiniwak natimihk ohci, itêyihtam;
sentences.english: Then the young man thought, “This is the time when the people from the west always arrive.
I had better try to see them.
Surely some Plains Cree will be in the river-gang,” he thought.

sentences.original: pôtih tâpwê wâpamêw owâhkomâkana nêhiyawa, âtiht êkotah nêhiyawak êh-atoskêcik, êwako pêyak mac-ôhôw.
sentences.text: pôti tâpwê wâpamêw owâhkômâkana nêhiyawa âtiht êkota nêhiyawak ê-atoskêcik êwako pêyak mac-ôhôw
sentences.english: And really it turned out that he did see some of his Plains Cree kinsmen, for a number of Cree were working with the gang, and one of them was Bad-Owl.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki omaskêkôwak êkotah ayâwak, awa ka-manitôwit kisêyiniw ê-pakosêyimot kîkwah ta-miyiht, astisah êh-miyiht mâna, êhtasiyit owîkimâkana kiyikaw âtiht ayôwinisah êh-miyimiht,
sentences.text: êkwa ôki omaskêkôwak êkota ayâwak awa ka-manitôwit kisêyiniw ê-pakosêyimot kîkway ta-miyiht astisa ê-miyiht mâna êhtasiyit owîkimâkana kiyikaw âtiht ayiwinisa ê-miyimiht
sentences.english: And those Swampy Cree were there too, and the old man who had manitou power was there, hoping to be given something, for always he was given gloves, and each and all of his wives were given clothing;

sentences.original: ôki wêmistikôsiwak êh-miyâcik, êh-kostâcik, êh-mac-âyîwiyit ôhi omaskêkôwa.
sentences.text: ôki wêmistikôsiwak ê-miyâcik ê-kostâcik ê-mac-âyiwiyit ôhi omaskêkôwa
sentences.english: the White People gave him these things, because they feared him, for an ugly customer was that Mushkago.
Then at one time that Mushkago came to seize her.

sentences.original: êkotah ayâw mac-ôhôw; sisonê sîpîhk itah ê-kîskatâwahkâyik, cîk êkotah ayâw.
sentences.text: êkota ayâw mac-ôhôw sisonê sîpîhk ita ê-kîskatâwahkâyik cîki êkota ayâw
sentences.english: Bad-Owl was there; on the steep bluff at the edge of the river, close by there he was staying.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê ôhi oskinîkiskwêwa kâ-wâpamât, mâ kîhkîhkan! kiwâpamitin, pikoh ta-wîkimitân! itêw.
sentences.english: Presently, when he saw that young woman, “Dear me, it must come in spite of anything! I have seen you, and now there is nothing but I must marry you!” he said to her.
He had not yet come to beg for things.
He was too intent on taking the woman for himself and taking her home with him.
So he used force.
Then on the way home, this far from them, they saw him.
At that the woman began to wail.
He will tear my child from me, this man who means to take me with him!

sentences.original: osâm êh-kitimâkisiyit nitawâsimisah nika-kitiskipitamâk, nistêsê! k-êtiht awa mac-ôhôw.
sentences.english: My poor child he will tear away from me, 0 my brother,” Bad-Owl was told.

sentences.original: nistêsê, awa niwî-kitiskipitamâk nitawâsimisah! êh-itiht awa mac-ôhôw, êw-oskinîkit, âsay êh-wîwit, êkosi sêmâk kisiwâsiw.
sentences.text: ê-itiht awa mac-ôhôw ê-oskinîkit âsay ê-wîwit êkosi sêmâk kisiwâsiw
sentences.english: When Bad-Owl was told, “Brother, he will tear my child from me!” being a young man and himself already married, at once he grew angry.
“You too were born of a woman!
It seems that you do anything that comes into your head!” he said to the other.
sentences.footnote: The translation follows the text; probably however, the last word is a slip of the tongue or an error of record for {ka-tôtên}, giving the meaning: “You will do whatever you want,” i.e., “I shall have to take the consequences of interfering with you; I cannot do other than I am doing.”

sentences.english: He rose to his feet and made for him.
In those days Bad-Owl was strong.

sentences.original: otinêw ôhi kisêyiniwa; sakipitonênêw; itohtahêw kîskatâwahkâhk.
sentences.text: otinêw ôhi kisêyiniwa sakipitonênêw itohtahêw kîskatâwahkâhk
sentences.english: He took hold of the old man; he gripped him by the arms; he walked him over to the steep bluff.

sentences.original: êh-âta-nakît awa kisêyiniw kâ-manitôwit, wêpinâw; nipîhk pakastawêhwâw; kôkîpayiw.
sentences.text: ê-âta-nakît awa kisêyiniw kâ-manitôwit wêpinâw nipîhk pakastawêhwâw kôkîpayiw
sentences.english: In vain the old man who was a manitou tried to stop; he threw him down; he threw him into the water; under he went.
Bad-Owl picked up an axe.
When the other came to land, “Have I made you angry?” he asked him.

sentences.original: êhâw, ntôtêm, namoya kikisiwâhin! ayîs nitôtamâson! itik.
sentences.english: “Yah, Fellow-Tribesman, you have not made me angry! I brought it on myself!” the other told him.
“You see, I was going to kill you, if I had incurred your anger.”
“Yes, Fellow-Tribesman; I brought it upon myself.
So this woman is your sister!

sentences.original: nama nântaw ntêyihtên ôma kâ-tôtawiyan, itik.
sentences.english: I do not mind what you have done to me,” he told him.

sentences.original: êkwah ôki atâwêwikamikohk, pêyak êh-okimâwit sêkisiw, osâm ê-kostât ôhi kâ-pakastawêhomiht.
sentences.text: êkwa ôki atâwêwikamikohk pêyak ê-okimâwit sêkisiw osâm ê-kostât ôhi kâ-pakastawêhomiht
sentences.english: Then of those people in the trading post, the one who was at the head became frightened, for he feared the man who had been thrown into the water.
So he said, “Now, go away from here!
Like fools you will be fearing this greasy old scab,” he said.
sentences.footnote: LB:  The white man's words are no doubt correctly quoted; but the Indians take them for mere bravado, and assume that the white man shares their fear of the old sorceror.  Else, why does he give him presents?

sentences.english: Accordingly they set out.
“Let me sit in the rear of the canoe,” said Bad-Owl.
“Very well,” he was told.

sentences.original: hâw, êkwah ê-pôsicik, êh-nimitawâhahkik, ômis îtwêw awa kâ-manitôwit : kêyiwêhk kik-âswêyimin, ntôtêm, ôma kâ-tôtawiyan, itwêw;
sentences.text: hâw êkwa ê-pôsicik ê-nimitawahahkik ômisi itwêw awa kâ-manitôwit itwêw
sentences.english: Then, when they had embarked to go west on the river, that one who had manitou power spoke as follows: “Just the same. you will look out for me, Fellow-Tribesman, in view of what you have done to me,” he said;
“You are the first to treat me that way.
As now you go on your river voyage, you will continue to be on your guard as you go along.

sentences.original: êyakonih miyâskamani, êkotah mîna kik-âswêyihtên; nôskinîkîm kika-wâpamâw.
sentences.english: And if you pass the things that will be on your way, also, you will be on your guard; you will see my servant.

sentences.original: êyakoh miyâskamani, itah kapêsiyini, nicêmisis êkwah kika-wâpamâw.
sentences.english: And if you pass this, there where you camp you will see my little pet beast.

sentences.original: miyâskawâci, oski-pipohki, êkotah êkwah nôskinikîm kik-âswêyimâw; êwakôw ana nama ka-kî-miyâskawâw, itik ôhi omaskêkôwa ka-mantôwiyit.
sentences.english: And if you pass him, then yonder you will look out for my servant; and this last one you will not pass,” he was told by that Mushkago who was a manitou.

sentences.original: katisk ê-nêyâyik êh-awasêwêskahkik, kîtahtawê kêkway pahkihtiniyiw ospiskwanihk.
sentences.text: katisk ê-nêyâyik ê-awasêwêskahkik kîtahtawê kêkway pahkihtiniyiw ospiskwanihk
sentences.english: As soon as they had passed the first sharp bend in the river, suddenly something fell on his back.
When he did like this, it turned out to be a beaver-bug.
He threw it away.

sentences.original: tahkih kâh-kiyipa otihtikôw kêkwa, awa omaskêkôw êy-itisahahk.
sentences.text: tahki kâh-kiyipa otihtikôw kêkway awa omaskêkôw ê-itisahahk
sentences.english: Unceasingly, at short intervals things reached him, things which the Swampy Cree had sent.

sentences.original: piyis mistahi kêkway, nanâtohk manicôsah, kiyikâw pîwâpiskwah, kiyikaw mistikohk êh-ohtinamiyit kêkwah, êkâ ê-pikwaskâkot awa mac-ôhôw, kahkiyaw mêstâskwêsin awa ômaskêkôw.
sentences.text: piyis mistahi kêkway nanâtohk manicôsa kiyikaw pîwâpiskwa kiyikaw mistikohk ê-ohtinamiyit kêkway êkâ ê-pikwâskâkot awa mac-ôhôw kahkiyaw mêstâskwêsin awa omaskêkôw
sentences.english: But, in time, when Bad-Owl was not pierced by the many things, by the various insects, by the metal things of every kind or by all the things which the other took from trees, then at last that Swampy Cree had used all his weapons.
Bad-Owl did not care to retaliate.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê, ê-mêkwâ-pimiskâcik sîpîhk, kîtahtawê kâ-pê-nôkwaniyik nipiy êh-pê-cimatêyik.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-mêkwâ-pimiskâcik sîpîhk kîtahtawê kâ-pê-nôkwaniyik nipiy ê-pê-cimatêyik
sentences.english: Presently as they were canoeing along the river, there suddenly appeared an upright wall of water.

sentences.original: êkwah awa otatâwêw, mac-ôhôw, nimâkohik awa ka-wîh-ôtihtikoyahk.
sentences.english: Then the trader said, “Bad-Owl, I dread this which is about to come upon us.

sentences.original: kîspin sâkohtâyini, pêyakwasâkay mihkwêkin kika-miyitin, êkwah ôma iskotêwâpoy, itêw.
sentences.english: If you can deal with it, I will give you enough red flannel for one dress, and this whiskey,” he told him.
“Very well!
That is no beast; it is a whirlwind.
I have seen the like of it.”
“Very well.

sentences.original: miyâhkan ôma mihkwêkin, itwêw aw ôtâtawêw.
sentences.english: If he succeeds give him this red flannel,” said the trader.
“Oh, do not come here in your course!
Be still!
I have seen you and can witness that you have obeyed the command which sent you here!” he told it;

sentences.original: kiyâm apih! êkâya wiyah kîwê! itêw.
sentences.english: “Be quiet! Do not come back!” he told it.
And truly there was no wind.
“Now, after this, nothing more will frighten us.

sentences.original: êkwah piko ocêmisisah kitôtêminaw, itwêw awa mac-ôhôw.
sentences.english: Now there will be only our fellow-tribesman's serving beast,” said Bad-Owl.
So then he was given the whiskey.

sentences.original: minahêw ôhi kâ-kîh-pêh-itisahomiht; mîn ôma mihkwêkin k-âsotamâht wîhtamawêw ê-wîh-miyât, iyikohk miyihci.
sentences.text: minahêw ôhi kâ-kî-pê-itisahomiht mîna ôma mihkwêkin kâ-asotamâht wîhtamawêw ê-wî-miyât iyikohk miyihci
sentences.english: He made a libation for him who had been sent there; and he told him that he would give him also all of the red flannel that he had been promised.
Then in the evening they landed and pitched camp.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê kâ-pêh-nôkwaniyik; iskotêw tâpiskôc itêyihtam awa otatâwêw.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê kâ-pê-nôkwaniyik iskotêw tâpiskôc itêyihtam awa otatâwêw
sentences.english: Presently something appeared; it seemed like a fire to the trader.
“Come, Bad-Owl, try to do something about this!

sentences.original: kika-miyitin cî ayôwinisah ta-postayôwinisêyan ? itêw awa otatâwêw.
sentences.english: Shall I give you clothing to wear?” the trader asked him.

sentences.original: êkosi nakiskawêw awa mac-ôhôw; at-ôtinêw minahikwâhtikwah, êy-wih-pakamahwât.
sentences.text: êkosi nakiskawêw awa mac-ôhôw ati-otinêw minahikwâhtikwa ê-wî-pakamahwât
sentences.english: So Bad-Owl went to meet it; as he went he took up the stem of a spruce with which to strike it.
When he came near, it fled.
The great cat and the great wolf feared Bad-Owl.
So the members of the trading party reached their homes.
Nothing more occurred to frighten them.
Then Bad-Owl stayed with his father-in-law.

sentences.original: ê-oski-piponiyik, papâmi-nôcihcikêwak, môswah, kahkiyaw kêkwah atâwâkanah ê-wîh-kakwê-nipahâcik.
sentences.text: ê-oski-piponiyik papâmi-nôcihcikêwak môswa kahkiyaw kêkway atâwâkana ê-wî-kakwê-nipahâcik
sentences.english: In the early winter they began to hunt far and wide, meaning to kill moose and all kinds of fur-bearing game.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-atih-âkwâ-piponiyik, kîtahtawê nama kêkway kih-nipahtâwak omanâcimâkanah.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê ê-ati-âkwâ-piponiyik kîtahtawê nama kêkway kî-nipahtâwak omanâcimâkana
sentences.english: Presently, as winter progressed, there came a time when he and his father-in-law could not kill anything.
There came a time when they could barely get home, being starved nearly to death.
To be sure, they would see game, but someone always scared it off.
His father-in-law and he could kill nothing.
At last they grew weak.

sentences.original: ây-êtatâw takosinwak, iyâta-mâcîtwâwi, êkâ kêkway wîhkâc êhmîcicik.
sentences.text: ay-êtataw takosinwak iyâta-mâcîtwâwi êkâ kêkway wîhkâc êhmîcicik
sentences.english: They could scarcely reach home each time, hunt as they might, for they never had anything to eat.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê âsay otawâsimisiwak owîkimâkana awa mac-ôhôw.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê âsay otawâsimisiwak owîkimâkana awa mac-ôhôw
sentences.english: Now, Bad-Owl and his wife had at that  time a child.

sentences.original: hâw, ninahâhkisîm, nama nânitaw nikîh-tôtên niya.
sentences.english: “Now then, Son-in-Law, as for me, I can do nothing.
There must be some reason for my not killing anything.
I have heard that you threw into the water a Mushkago who has manitou power.

sentences.original: êwakw êtok âna kâ-tôtâsk êkâ kêkway k-ô-kih-nipahtâyin! itâw.
sentences.english: I daresay he is the cause of your not being able to kill anything!” he was told.
He did not say anything.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê mîna ê-tipiskâyik kâ-takosiniyit omanâcimâkana, hwhw! êh-itwêyit, êh-ayêskomoyit.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê mîna ê-tipiskâyik kâ-takosiniyit omanâcimâkana ê-itwêyit ê-ayêskomoyit
sentences.english: Then, the next night, again came his father-in-law, breathing with the sound of one who has no strength left.
“Come in!”
He came in, leaning on a cane.
Bad-Owl, too, for that matter, was weak with hunger.
Then the old man filled a pipe.
When he had filled it, he gave it to his son-in-law.
“Take this!
My Son-in-law, smoke!
If things go on this way, we shall starve to death!

sentences.original: miton isâkôcihik êkos âwa awa kitawâsimis kê-kitimâkisit, êkâ nântaw kîh-tôtamani.
sentences.english: If thus it is to be, greatly overcome is this child of yours and doomed to misery, if you can do nothing.
Close by here I have come upon the tracks of two moose.
'All I shall succeed in doing is to frighten them off,' I thought, and left it at having found their tracks.

sentences.original: mâskôc wâpahkih wîh-nâtahâhtaci, êy-itêyimitân, êkâ k-ôh-nayiwâmohkêyân, ninahâhkisîm, itêw.
sentences.english: Tomorrow perhaps you might follow the trail of them, I thought of you, and therefore took care not to frighten them off,” he said to him.
Only then did Bad-Owl remember his dream guardian.
sentences.footnote: A pair of moose is the Bony Spectre's characteristic gift.

sentences.english: “Oho! Was not the last the Bony Spectre said to me, 'You shall hunt nothing in vain!'?
Come, I shall hunt this very night!”  he thought.

sentences.original: êkwah owîkimâkana, êkâ cêkwa êw-ohci-kikaskisinêhk, itêw, maskisina, êh-kakwêcimât.
sentences.english: Then he said to his wife, “Some moccasins that have never yet been worn,” he questioned her.
“There are these here,” his wife answered him.
“Give them here.”
He was given them.

sentences.original: kê-kêtaskisinêw, êwakoni ê-postiskahk; kah-kaskitênahk ositah, postaskisinêw.
sentences.text: kê-kêtaskisinêw êwakoni ê-postiskahk ka-kaskitênahk osita postaskisinêw
sentences.english: He took off the moccasins he was wearing, and put on the others; after blacking his feet with charred wood, he put them on.
“Give me my knife,” he said to her.
She gave it him.
He made ready to go.

sentences.original: nnahâhkisîm, êkosî cî ê-wih-mâciyan ? itêw awa kisêyiniw.
sentences.english: “Son-in-Law, is it like this you mean to hunt?” the old man asked him.
“Yes,” he said to him.
“Be careful, at any rate!” his father-in-law said to him;
“The path by which I came here, you will follow.
In time you will come upon their tracks.
They cannot yet be far off,” he told him.
Thereupon he went out of the lodge.
He followed back his father-in-law's trail.

sentences.original: kêtahtawê mâtâhêw itah êh-pimohtêyit ôhi môswa.
sentences.text: kêtahtawê mâtâhêw ita ê-pimohtêyit ôhi môswa
sentences.english: Presently he came upon the tracks where two moose had gone by.
“Come now, you told me I should hunt nothing in vain!

sentences.original: maht ôki nama nika-môsihikwak ôki môswak!
sentences.english: Let it be now that these moose do not perceive my approach!

sentences.original: kik-âsamitin ci pimiy ? itêw ôhi pâkahkosah.
sentences.english: Shall I give you fat to eat?” he said to that Bony Spectre.
Thereupon he followed their trail.
When he thought them  near, he took off his snowshoes; he walked on the snow.
Presently he saw a fallen tree lying across his path.
When he came to it, from  behind it one rose to its feet.
He fired at it; he loaded again.

sentences.original: êh-itâpit, kotakah wâpamêw; mîn êyakonih pâskiswêw.
sentences.text: ê-itâpit kotaka wâpamêw mîna êwakoni pâskiswêw
sentences.english: When he looked, he saw the other one; he shot it too.

sentences.original: êkosi mêscihêw, ê-tipiskâyik, ê-nîpâ-mâcît, ôhi môswa.
sentences.text: êkosi mêscihêw ê-tipiskâyik ê-nîpâ-mâcît ôhi môswa
sentences.english: So he killed both of those moose, in the night, hunting in the dark.
He took the ribs; he skinned and cut up the carcasses.
When he had piled up the cuts of meat, he went home.

sentences.original: wiy ôki êh-pêhtahkik nîso, nîswâw êh-matwêwêyik, nanâskomôw awa kisêyiniw.
sentences.text: wiya ôki ê-pêhtahkik nîso nîswâw ê-matwêwêyik nanâskomôw awa kisêyiniw
sentences.english: When those others heard the two reports, the old man gave thanks.

sentences.original: namoya kont êh-mâcît! itêyimêw onahâhkisîma, êh-tipiskâyik êh-mâciyit.
sentences.english: “He has not gone on a fruitless hunt!” he thought of his son-in-law who hunted in the night.

sentences.original: êh-takosihk awa mac-ôhôw, pîhtokêwêpinam ôhi ospikêkanah.
sentences.text: ê-takosihk awa mac-ôhôw pîhtokêwêpinam ôhi ospikêkana
sentences.english: When Bad-Owl arrived, he threw the ribs into the lodge.
He gave thanks.
“Ho, not yet! Wait a bit, Daughter!
Prepare some warm water.
We have been too long without food.
Let us vomit first.”
So they prepared the water.
Then, when they had vomited the woman cooked the food.
“Ho, it was right close by here that I killed them!”

sentences.original: ê-mêkwâh-mîcisocik, kâ-pimi-mâtôwiht, nayêwâc aspin mâmihk êy-isi-mâtôwiht.
sentences.text: ê-mêkwâ-mîcisocik kâ-pimi-mâtôwiht nayêwâc aspin mâmihk ê-isi-mâtôwiht
sentences.english: As they ate, the sound of wailing went by, through the air; dying off toward the east, went the sound of wailing.

sentences.original: êyakoni omaskêkôwa êh-mahyakomikocik, k-âti-mâtoyit, ê-sâkôcihât awa mac-ôhôw.
sentences.text: êwakoni omaskêkôwa ê-mahyakomikocik kâ-ati-mâtoyit ê-sâkôcihât awa mac-ôhôw
sentences.english: That was the Mushkago who had given them ill luck, who went off wailing, now that Bad-Owl had defeated him.

sentences.original: êkosi êkwah tâpiskôc ê-wêhcasiniyik kêkwah ê-nipahtâcik, atâwâkanah kiyikaw.
sentences.text: êkosi êkwa tâpiskôc ê-wêhcasiniyik kêkway ê-nipahtâcik atâwâkana kiyikaw
sentences.english: After that it seemed as though it were an easy thing for them to kill things, fur-bearing game of every kind.
Now when they again go down the river, I shall go along.

sentences.original: kiyâm êkâ masinahikêyicih awiyak, nika-pimitisahikân, itêyihtam.
sentences.english: Even if no one employs me, I shall follow the party,” he thought.

sentences.original: êh-nîpiniyik iyikohk, ispiciwak wâskahikanihk, iyikohk êy-ispîhtâwaniyik, mâna êkoyikohk ê-mâhamoht.
sentences.text: ê-nîpiniyik iyikohk ispiciwak wâskahikanihk iyikohk ê-ispîhtâwaniyik mâna êkoyikohk ê-mâhamoht
sentences.english: When spring came, they moved their camp to the trading post, when the season had come for the usual down-river trip.

sentences.original: mayaw ê-wâpamikot otâtâwêyiwa, hâw, mac-ôhôw, kitakosinin!
sentences.english: As soon as the trader saw him, “Well, Bad-Owl, so you are here!”
“Yes!”
“My men are about to go down the river.
You may go along with them.
There will be one clerk with the party.
But you will be the head man until you arrive yonder.

sentences.original: namoya kik-âtoskân, itik otâtâwêwa, ka-tipêyihtaman kêkwah ta-pê-pimohtatâhk, mina ta-sipwêhtatâhk.
sentences.english: You shall not work,” the trader told him, “but you shall be the master over the things that are to be carried and over those which are to be taken away.

sentences.original: min ôki nâpêwak, têpiyâhk awa kit-âkihtahk kêkwah atâwâkanah; kiya namoya : pikoh kita-wîhtamôwacik tânisi kit-ês-âtoskêcik, mîna kita-nipâcik pikw îsi, itwêw mac-ôhôw.
sentences.english: And as for these men, this one is only to count up the goods and the  furs; not you: you are merely to tell them what to do as they work, and where to stop for the night,” Bad-Owl was told.
He agreed at once.
He went with the gang.

sentences.original: â, tâpwê! hâh, ay-apisîs kêkway kika-miyâwâw aw omaskêkôw, itâw awa, êh-itwêt mac-ôhôw; iyikohk mâna kâ-miyâyêk, âstam iyikohk, itâw.
sentences.english: “Oh, yes! Of course. Now, you are to give that Swampy Cree only a bit of the different things,” that man was told, and it was Bad-Owl who spoke; “Less than you have been in the habit of giving him,” he was told.

sentences.original: êkosi mâhamwak, atâwâkanah ê-sipwêhtahâcik, pikw êkwah ê-kakwêcimiht mac-ôhôw, tânsi kit-êsi-atoskêyit ôhi omâhamwa.
sentences.text: êkosi mâhamwak atâwâkana ê-sipwêhtahâcik piko êkwa ê-kakwêcimiht mac-ôhôw tânisi kita-isi-atoskêyit ôhi omâhamwa
sentences.english: So then they started down-stream, with their load of furs, and at every point Bad-Owl was asked to say how that river-gang was to work.

sentences.original: êkosi kisiwâk êh-ayâcik, awa omaskêkôw ispiciw.
sentences.text: êkosi kisiwâk ê-ayâcik awa omaskêkôw ispiciw
sentences.english: Then, when they got near, that Mushkago moved his camp thither.

sentences.original: otôtâma kahkiyaw mihcêtokamikisiw, kahkiyaw ta-miyimiht kêkwah, mîciwinah, nanâtohk kêkwa, êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.text: otôtêma kahkiyaw mihcêtokamikisiw kahkiyaw ta-miyimiht kêkway mîciwina nanâtohk kêkway ê-itêyihtahk
sentences.english: He came with all his kinsmen, a camp of many tents, for he thought they would all be given things, foodstuffs, and all manner of goods.

sentences.original: êkwah êh-ôtâkosiniyik, awin ôhi, mihcêt wâpahtamwak sisonê sîpîhk êh-ayâyiki waskwayikamikwah.
sentences.text: êkwa ê-otâkosiniyik awîna ôhi mihcêt wâpahtamwak sisonê sîpîhk ê-ayâyiki waskwayikamikwa
sentences.english: So then, towards evening, what did they see but a whole camp of birch-bark tents standing by the river's edge!
hen, “Here you will go ashore, and we shall camp for the night.

sentences.original: âkâya wîhtamâhk ana omaskêkôw kâ-mac-âyiwit, itwêw;
sentences.english: Do not tell that Mushkago who is such a dangerous person,” he said;
“I shall stay here in the canoe,” said Bad-Owl;
“We shall camp right here,” he said.
They did as he said; they beached their canoes.
He stayed right there.
A Swampy Cree, a young man, came where he was.

sentences.original: ômis îtik : kiya cî kâ-kîh-pakastawêhwat nôkimâminân ? itik.
sentences.english: This man said to him, “Was it you threw our chief into the water?”
“Yes.”
“Ha, he does not suspect you are here.
'I daresay we shall never again see that Bad-Owl, as our fellow-tribesmen called him,' he always says, and that is why I wanted to take a look at you,” he told him.

sentences.original: êkosi ômis îtwêw mac-ôhôw : tân-tahto êhtasiyit owîkimâkana ?
sentences.english: Then Bad-Owl said, “How many wives has he?”
“Ten,” the other told him.
“Very well! I shall take one of them,” he told him.

sentences.original: hâ, tâpwêh cimisisiw; kêhtêskwêwiw; êyako piko êyakoni mâmawêyisk êh-sâkihât, itik;
sentences.english: “Ho, there is one short, little one, an old woman; she is the only one of the whole lot that he cares for,” the other told him;
“The others are all young women.

sentences.original: nîsta pêyak niwîkimâkana ê-kîh-otinât, êkwah êkâ ê-kî-paskêwihak, ê-kostak, osâm êh-manitôwit, êkâ wîhkâc nîso-kîsikâw awiya êh-pimâtisiyit, kîspin niyôcihâci.
sentences.english: From me too he took a wife, and I cannot get her away from him, for I fear him; I fear that he will kill me by the aid of his dream spirits, for he is a manitou person, and no one ever lives two days whom he seeks to destroy.

sentences.original: êwakôw ohci tân-tahto ôtah ntayânân, ê-maskamikoyâhk niwîkimâkaninâna.
sentences.english: For this cause, I know not how many of us are here whose wives he has taken away.
He is a dangerous and evil being,” the other told him.

sentences.original: hâg, êkâya wîhtamâhk, pê-takosihki, itêw ôhi.
sentences.english: “Ha, do not tell him, if he comes here,” he told the man.

sentences.original: kêswân ,- kîwêw awa omaskêkôw oskinîkiw ,- êh-ati-takohtêt, kâ-pê-wayawiyit ôhi kâ-manitôwiyit;
sentences.text: kêswân kîwêw awa omaskêkôw oskinîkiw ê-ati-takohtêt kâ-pê-wayawiyit ôhi kâ-manitôwiyit
sentences.english: It happened, - the young Swampy Cree went back to his camp, - it happened that as he reached the camp, the one who had manitou power was coming out of his tent;
it was well on towards nightfall.
He was coming with all his wives.
They came to where he was.

sentences.original: tân âna mâka êh-okimâwit ôma ka-pê-pimiskâyêk, kâ-pêw-otôtêmiyêk ?
sentences.english: “But which one, now, is the chief of your canoe party, of your party of tribesmen?
As always, you have come now to your follow-tribesmen.

sentences.original: kêkway êtokê ka-sa-sawêyimâwâwak, tahto k-êhtasiyêk, ôki niwîkimâkanak ta-têpêyihtahkik ?
sentences.english: What little present will you give them, as many as you are? What will you give my wives here to have as their own?
Surely you will give them something.

sentences.original: mân ôt âni wiya ntôtêm pêyak ôtah êkâ niwâpamâh!
sentences.english: But that one fellow-tribesman of mine I do not see here!

sentences.original: awîna wêkimâwikwêh, êkw ana niya kê-sa-sawêyimit kêkwa, mîn ôhi niwîkimâkana, kîkwâs kit-ôy-ohtinamowât.
sentences.english: Whoever is chief, he will give me some little things, and he will manage to scrape up some trifle for my wives here.

sentences.original: êkwah kiyawâw nîsta ntôskinîkîmak ta-ôhtinamôwâyêkik êy-âpisîs têpiyâhk; êkosi ta-na-nahêyihtâkwan, itwêw awa omaskêkôw.
sentences.english: And the rest of you will take from your stock some little thing at least for each of my men; in this way everyone will be satisfied,” said that Mushkago.

sentences.original: hâ, ntawi-ntômihk kitôkimâminaw, itâw awa mac-ôhôw.
sentences.english: “Well, go call your chief,” was said of Bad-Owl.
Then he came to shore from his canoe.
“Why! It is none other than my fellow-tribesman!
What little gifts shall I pick out for him, I wonder?”

sentences.original: êyako cî mac-ôhôw kây-itâkaniwit, ôtah kâ-kîh-pâhpisihitoyâhk ?
sentences.english: “Why, is this Bad-Owl, as he was called, with whom I used to play here at practical jokes?”
“Yes, he it is!” he told him.
“Oh, Fellow-Tribesman, I will do whatever you say.”

sentences.original: nhâ, ntôtêm, pêyak nnôhtêh-kîwêhtahâw iskwêw kitiskwêmiwâwak.
sentences.english: “Well then, Fellow-Tribesman, I should like to take home with me one woman from among your women.”

sentences.original: êhag, ntôtêm, ôki mâka mâna mâka piko ê-tipêyimakik, mitâtaht ôki k-âpicik.
sentences.english: “Yes, Fellow-Tribesman, I have only these ten who are sitting here.

sentences.original: êyakoni mâna mâka piko pêyak kik-ôtinâw, pikw âna ê-wîh-otinat, itik awa mac-ôhôw omaskêkôwa.
sentences.english: They are all I have, but one of them you may take, whichever one you wish,” said the Swampy Cree to Bad-Owl.
Secretly the other man pointed out to him the old woman of whom he had told him.
He stopped up to one after the other, to see which one he would take.

sentences.original: mihcêt mâna mâka miyosiwak, ntôtêm, itêw aw ômaskêkôw.
sentences.english: “Most of them are handsome indeed, Fellow-Tribesman,” the Mushkago said to him.

sentences.original: pikw ânihi ê-sâkihâyit wîwiyiwa, êyakoni otinêw.
sentences.text: piko anihi ê-sâkihâyit wîwiyiwa êwakoni otinêw
sentences.english: The wife whom the other loved, that was the one he took.

sentences.original: êyahâ, ntôtêm! kôskinîkin, kâ-kacâc êh-nôtokêwit k-ôtinat, mihcêt ôk êh-miyosicik!
sentences.english: “Dear me, Fellow-Tribesman! You are a young man, to be taking just the one who is old, when these others are so handsome!”
“Well, it happens that this is my choice, and so I am taking this one.

sentences.original: hâw, êkwah mâka, ntôtêm, kîwêhtah ôkih kitiskwêmak! itêw omaskêkôwa;
sentences.english: There now, Fellow-Tribesman, go home with your women!” he told the Swampy Cree;
“You are not to go anywhere else tonight.
Tomorrow I shall try to see you once more.”

sentences.original: êkwah ôhi k-ôtinât iskwêwa kont îtah nipâyiwa.
sentences.text: êkwa ôhi kâ-otinât iskwêwa konita ita nipâyiwa
sentences.english: Then the woman he had taken slept somewhere or other.
He did not sleep with her.
In the morning he took her over there.
“Ha, come in, Tribesman!” he said to him.
He entered.
All the Mushkago's followers came there.

sentences.original: â, ntôtêm, êh awa nikih-otinâw, ê-wîh-kîwêhtahak, mâka kinîmâskwâkana ôhi ka-wêpinaman.
sentences.english: “Now then, Fellow-Tribesman, I have taken this woman and mean to take her home with me, unless you abandon the weapons which you use.”
“Yes, I shall do that.
Whatever you say, I shall do.
I love her too much whom you have taken.”

sentences.original: êhag, ntôtêm, kâwih kika-miyitin, êkâ wîhkâc kîhtwâm êkosi ta-tôtaman;
sentences.english: “Very well, Fellow-Tribesman, I will give her back to you, on condition that never again you do as you have done.
I shall strike down your helpers to the very last one.
'I shall give him one more interview.
If he is not willing to do as I shall tell him, then let him in turn see my familiar beasts and wrestle with them,' is what I thought concerning you.
But now you shall again have this wife of yours.

sentences.original: pikoh wâh-itâhpihiskik kôskinîkîmak, k-êtâhpihikwak ôki kôskinîkîmak.
sentences.english: In whatever way your followers may feel inclined to laugh at you, they will laugh at you.
And these women are to go back from wherever you have taken them.
If you do not do so, I shall destroy you beyond redemption.”
“Yes, Fellow-Tribesman, I will do so;
I wish to live.
I am fond only of the one you took.
These others may go back to their relatives.”
“You have altogether too many wives.
I shall not fail to hear of it, if you do any more killing.
And so now I forbid you to exercise any more evil arts.”
“Yes, Fellow-Tribesman, I shall do this which you say;

sentences.original: osâm nnôhtê-pimâtisin, mîn âwa niwîwikimâkan ê-sâkihak.
sentences.english: I want to live, and I love this wife of mine.
You will see that they go home.”
Then he took him at his word.

sentences.original: wayawîwak, nanânis êy-isi-kîwêcik ôki kotakak iskwêwak, êkotah ohci êsa kâ-kîh-kostikot omaskêkôwa awa mac-ôhôw.
sentences.text: wayawîwak nanânis ê-isi-kîwêcik ôki kotakak iskwêwak êkota ohci êsa kâ-kî-kostikot omaskêkôwa awa mac-ôhôw
sentences.english: They went out of the tipi, and those other women went to their several homes, and all because evidently the Mushkago feared Bad-Owl.
That is the end of the story.
